data.title: Site of the first computer ever assembled.
data.text: I happen to live on the same street as this historic site, so I pass it every day as I ride my bike out to Stanford University.  There is a boulder with a brass plaque mounted to it which gives historical information about when Hewlet and Packard (two Stanford students @ the time) built the 1st computer in this small garage.  I see tourist here virtually daily and very often they are dropped off in large groups by tour buses, yet it sits on city streets, hence you could easily get yourself there via driving your own vehicle or simply by walking down tree- lined streets.

data.title: Had the opportunity to visit as part of a meeting at Hewlett Packard Enterprise
data.text: Interesting location especially if you have the possibility to go into the garage and the house where Hewlett and Packard founded HPand started silicon valley

data.title: Yup it is a garage viewed from a distance
data.text: Part of a business tour which decided it was worth a visit. If you are in a bus or large vehicle it is tricky to get there and navigate the cars parked in the residential neighborhood. Unless you are really one to get inspired by seeing these sort of places for yourself it is fine to look at it on a photo. You can't go inside or get closer than 50 meters from it. There are better things to do.

data.title: Cool. What else?
data.text:
Interesting from a historical perspective, but there's not much to do here other than visit, read the plaque, maybe take a picture. There are no tours and you can't go inside. You'll see that it's in a residential neighborhood and people actually live in the surrounding homes. But that's it. 

It's worth a stop if you're nearby. But I wouldn't make special plans just to go here.

data.title: Not just any garage, but still, a garage
data.text: It is a must see for what it represents... as a tourist landmark, well it really is "the garage" of a PRIVATE residence.  Drive, park your car, look at the garage, have a few moment to absorb what happened there if you are a fan, then take a picture and go.  There is nothing else to do or see in the area, except to look at the nice houses :-)

data.title: A house like many others
data.text:
Hi, 

i visited the "garage" in february. Don't expect an wow. it's a house on the street, like many other neighboring houses. Has that card saying about its history. 
At the time I was there, I could not enter the house or yard.

data.title: All Good Things are started in a Garage
data.text: Instead of rocking out in a band, Bill Hewlett and Dave Packard started making oscillators out of this garage a short time after graduating from Stanford University in the 1930's.  Famously, Disney asked Bill to make a few tweaks here and there to their existing models so that they could be used for the surround sound speaker systems in the dozen theaters that showed the original movie Fantasia.  HP later went on to make printers, computers, software, and gets credit as the founder of Silicon Valley.

data.title: It's a garage. But it's not any old garage
data.text: "Do we have to go and see a garage?", whined the kids? Yes we do. Like Star Tours in Hollywood you're just driving past a house--nay, garage--but it's not just any old house, or any old garage.  Soak up what this garage represents.  And when you're loving Downtown Palo Alto and all it has to offer thank Bill and Dave--and their Stanford Professor--for having the courage to go it alone.  The rest, as they say, is history!

data.title: Thanks to Bill and Dave.
data.text: Hewlett-Packard helped start my technology company in the '80s.  It was important to stop streetside on a quiet morning and thank them again for the good life that they brought to my family and to many others.

data.title: Birthplace of HP
data.text: It was very interesting to see the birthplace of Silicon Valley.  To tour the house and garage, restored to era specific, was a great experience.  To think that Silicon Valley was born in that house in garage was inspiring.   A great experience.

data.title: Worth a quick visit just to say you saw it
data.text: You only need about 5 minutes to get out, see the garage from a distance, read the National Register of Historic Places sign and pause to realize that this tiny garage was the birthplace to Silicon Valley and the tech boom. After you do that, you'll be ready to move on. You can't go inside so you'll only see what's in the two attached pictures. As a result, don't go far out of your way for a visit. We were in the neighborhood for the UCF vs Stanford game so it was quick and easy for us to come and go and then be able to say that we've seen it. If you find yourself in a similar situation, stop by for a quick visit and move on. Be respectful of the fact that it is in a regular neighborhood so be mindful of where you park and how you and those in your party act while you visit.

data.title: Interesting to see.
data.text: Seeing the actual garage just makes the legend more real.  The fact that it's nothing to see really--just a garage--is fascinating.  Of course, it's in Palo Alto, so it's in a beautiful neighborhood.

data.title: Behind the curtain....
data.text: I'm a corporate trainer with Hewlett Packard and, in conjunction with a recent workshop, I was able to get behind the curtain at The Garage.  What an awesome experience!  But, even from the street, to see where Silicon Valley started is a once in a lifetime experience.

data.title: HP Garage, a piece of Tech history
data.text: It is not exactly a fantastic place, but it is so close to the main street, so it is worth walking by to see where the Silicon Valley started.

data.title: Here we are....birthplace of all tech.....
data.text: It would be good to have more pictures or something like a walkthrough museum for visitors who like to know more along the walk-way to the garage.

data.title: Fairly interesting historical landmark near a more interesting site.
data.text: This is the original garage at 367 Addison Avenue in Palo Alto where David Packard and Bill Hewlett began their early endeavors that eventually lead to the founding  of  Hewlett Packard.Corporation. The  house and garage were bought by HP when Carly Fiorina was CEO to be able to ensure it would be preserved. It is now a duplex and one can often see a bus or large shuttle parked nearby which has brought a load of tourists to jump off and take pictures. What is more interesting is that two blocks away at 551 Addison is the home of Marissa Meyer, the CEO of Yahoo. Several years ago she bought that house and the house  next door which she tore  down and put in a pool, guest house children's play house, etc. On the front lawn of that lot she has placed a giant bronze hippopotamus which appears to be partially submerged in the lawn. My grandkids always get a kick of looking at  that. At every holiday season she does major decorating as just now there are giant pumpkins, corn stalks, flying witches, etc.all around her front yard.

data.title: Symbolic & Historic
data.text: Symbolic by the historic fact of being a birthplace of Silicon Valley, but not much to see.... 5 minutes max.

data.title: Why do you need to see a plaque
data.text: I grew up around the corner. I get that this garage is historical but the constant passersby on this little neighborhood street who want to come and stare at it, is sort of ridiculous. It's just a garage, you can't go in. It's not a museum. People live there. Really, it's not worth it. Look at the picture posted above and move on.

data.title: HP History
data.text: The place is wonderful, where HP really started.  The were located in Palo Alto for years, now the company is spread around the world, but major locations in the Bay Area consist of Palo Alto & Cupertino.

data.title: Simple & iconic
data.text: Feeling good for HP employees to pay a visit and see this birth place face to face. Though we could just take some pictures outside.
